awd_titl_txt: Start SMART - Self-Motivated, Academic, Reflective, Talented
awd_abstract_narration:
The Start SMART - Self-Motivated, Academic, Reflective, Talented project of Lehigh Carbon Community College (LCCC) will provide scholarships for 90-100 academically talented and low-income students to increase their retention, degree completion, and transfer to baccalaureate programs. Students majoring in science, engineering, mathematics, computing, drafting, industrial automation, electronics technology, electrical technology, mechanical technology, and nanofabrication technology will participate as a cohort in structured activities to motivate them to persist in their STEM programs. These activities will include one-on-one mentoring with STEM faculty, orientation, monthly meetings featuring integrated learning labs, mathematics support, student-facilitated study groups, S-STEM buddies, presentations by professionals, workshops, field trips, STEM Club, and job/transfer fairs. Students will be required to create and maintain ePortfolios to record their goals, artifacts of coursework and activities, and ongoing reflections of their personal and professional development. The goal of the Start SMART program is to produce skilled graduates prepared to enter the STEM workforce. 

A research study will determine the correlation between the project's evidence-based strategies and the attributes of growth mindset, grit, goal orientation, self-regulation, and STEM momentum predicted to lead to academic success for community college students in STEM programs. The use of ePortfolios will serve a three-fold purpose: (1) enhancing student learning by helping them make connections across courses and activities; (2) enabling students to share their experiences and connect with each other and faculty; and (3) measuring STEM momentum through an analysis of students' artifacts and reflections. Integrative learning experiences will expand students' knowledge of other disciplines and instill professional skills necessary for the workplace. Research questions are: 1) To what extent do the non-cognitive variables of growth mindset, grit, goal orientation, and self-regulation change over the duration of the program? 2) Is there a correlation between the project activities and the non-cognitive variables that are predictive of student outcomes? 3) Is successful completion of the first mathematics course in the first year associated with STEM momentum? 4) To what extent does the ePortfolio demonstrate STEM momentum? Findings from the research study will expand on the concept of STEM momentum as it relates to community college students.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit                                                                                                              

 The students benefited from scholarship support. Students are able to focus on schoolwork and not have to consider working more to support themselves and their families. In addition, during a time of need, students were able to gain access to cover their expenses and still be enrolled in the classes. 

 

The students benefited from the educational support workshops provided in the monthly meetings. The monthly meetings provided students with an opportunity to gain access to resources that may not have been sought out otherwise. These resources ultimately served to assist academic achievement, confidence building, and community outreach. Students reported that they generally enjoyed the content of these sessions.

 

The students benefited from the mentoring. Mentoring helped students feel less nervous and offered them the practice of communicating with the faculty and experts. Faculty consciously allocated mentoring talks more time because they understand that these contacts are crucial to students' development rather than merely being pleasant.

 

Broader Impacts                                                                                                        STEM Scholars impact through STEM club. Scholars not only participated in the STEM club but also maintained leadership positions in the club. Being involved in on-campus activities helped with the student retention. 

 

Faculty benefited from the program. Faculty were able to have a better relationship with the students and in some cases maintain contact with the students after graduation. While working with the students, faculty were able to better understand student needs and provide individual support.

 

Impact of ePortfolio: Students were able to recognize their academic and personal achievements. ePortfolios encouraged students to take an active role in their learning and increase student engagement and motivation. One student stated ?we use it for school, but it?s a guideline for how to present yourself to the world, organize your achievements and goals.

 

Relationships with External Organizations: The College as a whole and individual students benefited through the outreach to outside organizations. Students were able to explore the opportunities available to them outside Lehigh Carbon Community College.

 

Positive Social Implications: The success of students involved in this project involves more than their academic lives. It has a positive impact on their lives in general, including the reality of a good paying job in a STEM field, a higher education beyond a two-year school, and other opportunities that may not be afforded to other student populations. Because the students in the program are highly-motivated, they have a natural desire to share their success with other students, friends, and family. These students tend to be involved in peer-to-peer mentoring, campus clubs, honor programs, honor societies, community events, and off-campus activities, which has a positive impact on the surrounding community as well as the campus community. 

 

 


Last Modified: 03/31/2023
Modified by: Deepika C Khilnaney
